# Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the names of Jesus. For other uses, see [Name of Christ
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Name_of_Christ_\(disambiguation\) "Name of Christ
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Ut_in_nomine_Jesu_Gesu_Rome.jpg/300px-
Ut_in_nomine_Jesu_Gesu_Rome.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ut_in_nomine_Jesu_Gesu_Rome.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ut_in_nomine_Jesu_Gesu_Rome.jpg "Enlarge")

Latin inscription of [Philippians
2:10](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Philippians#2:10
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Philippians"): "_At the name of Jesus
every knee should bow_ ", [Church of the Gesù](/wiki/Church_of_the_Ges%C3%B9
"Church of the Gesù"), Rome.

Two names and a variety of titles are used to refer to [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus
"Jesus") in the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament").[1]

In Christianity, the two names Jesus and [Emmanuel](/wiki/Emmanuel "Emmanuel")
that refer to Jesus in the New Testament have
[salvific](/wiki/Christian_salvation "Christian salvation")
attributes.[2][3][4] After the [Crucifixion of
Jesus](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus "Crucifixion of Jesus") the [early
Church](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early Christianity") did not simply repeat
his messages, but focused on him, proclaimed him, and tried to understand and
explain his message:.One element of the process of understanding and
proclaiming Jesus was the attribution of titles to him.[5] Some of the titles
that were gradually used in the early Church and then appeared in the New
Testament were adopted from the [Jewish context of the
age](/wiki/Jewish_Christianity "Jewish Christianity"), while others were
selected to refer to, and underscore the [message](/wiki/The_gospel "The
gospel"), [mission](/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus "Ministry of Jesus") and teachings
of Jesus.[5] In time, some of these titles gathered significant
[Christological](/wiki/Christology "Christology") significance.[6]

Christians have attached theological significance to the [Holy Name of
Jesus](/wiki/Holy_Name_of_Jesus "Holy Name of Jesus").[7][8] The use of the
name of Jesus in petitions is stressed in [John
16:23](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#16:23
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") when Jesus states: "If you ask
the Father anything in my name he will give it you."[9] There is widespread
belief among Christians that the name Jesus is not merely a sequence of
identifying symbols but includes intrinsic divine power.[4][9][10]

###
Jesus[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Jesus")]

See also: [Jesus (name)](/wiki/Jesus_\(name\) "Jesus \(name\)") and [Name of
God in Christianity](/wiki/Name_of_God_in_Christianity "Name of God in
Christianity")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Byzantinischer_Maler_um_1020_003.jpg/150px-
Byzantinischer_Maler_um_1020_003.jpg)](/wiki/File:Byzantinischer_Maler_um_1020_003.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Byzantinischer_Maler_um_1020_003.jpg "Enlarge")

Beginning of a [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine "Byzantine") copy of the [Gospel of
Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke "Gospel of Luke"), 1020. [Luke
1:31](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Luke#1:31
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Luke") states: "... bring forth a son,
and shalt call his name JESUS."[11]

In the New Testament the name Jesus is given both in the [Gospel of
Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke "Gospel of Luke") and the [Gospel of
Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew "Gospel of Matthew"), and
[Emmanuel](/wiki/Emmanuel "Emmanuel") only in Matthew. In [Luke
1:31](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Luke#1:31
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Luke") an angel tells Mary to name her
child Jesus, and in [Matthew
1:21](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#1:21
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") an angel tells Joseph to
name the child Jesus. The statement in Matthew 1:21 "you shall call his name
Jesus, for he will save his people from their sins" associates
[salvific](/wiki/Christian_soteriology "Christian soteriology") attributes to
the name Jesus in Christian theology.[2][3][12][13]

Although the precise difference between a 'name' and a 'title' may be open to
interpretation, 198 different names and titles of Jesus in the Bible are
listed in [Cruden's Concordance](/wiki/Cruden%27s_Concordance "Cruden's
Concordance"), first published in 1737, and continuously in print ever since.
The first index of the book (following the royal dedications and author's
preface) is entitled "A collection of the Names and Titles given to Jesus
Christ", with 198 names listed, each accompanied by a biblical reference.[14]

####
Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Etymology")]

There have been a number of proposals as to the origin and etymological origin
of the name Jesus (cf. [Matthew
1:21](https://www.biblica.com/bible/?osis=niv:Matthew.1:21–1:21)). The name is
related to the [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language") form
[Yehoshua`] יְהוֹשֻׁעַ‬ [Joshua](/wiki/Joshua "Joshua"), which is a
[theophoric name](/wiki/Theophoric_name "Theophoric name") first mentioned
within the [Biblical tradition](/wiki/Bible "Bible") in [Exodus
17:9](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0217.htm#9) referring to one of
[Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses")' companions (and his successor as leader of the
Israelites). This name is usually considered to be a compound of two parts:
יהו‬ _Yeho_ , a theophoric reference to [YHWH](/wiki/YHWH "YHWH"), the
distinctive personal name of the [God of Israel](/wiki/Yahweh "Yahweh"), plus
a form derived from the Hebrew [triconsonantal root](/wiki/Triconsonantal_root
"Triconsonantal root") _y-š-ʕ_ or י-ש-ע "to liberate, save". There have been
various proposals as to how the literal etymological meaning of the name
should be translated, including:[15][16][17][18][19]

    

  * YHWH saves
  * YHWH (is) salvation
  * YHWH (is) a saving-cry
  * YHWH (is) a cry-for-saving
  * YHWH (is) a cry-for-help
  * YHWH (is) my help

This early Biblical Hebrew name יְהוֹשֻׁעַ‬ [Yehoshua`] underwent a shortening
into later Biblical יֵשׁוּעַ‬ [Yeshua`], as found in the Hebrew text of verses
Ezra 2:2, 2:6, 2:36, 2:40, 3:2, 3:8, 3:9, 3:10, 3:18, 4:3, 8:33; Nehemiah
3:19, 7:7, 7:11, 7:39, 7:43, 8:7, 8:17, 9:4, 9:5, 11:26, 12:1, 12:7, 12:8,
12:10, 12:24, 12:26; 1 Chronicles 24:11; and 2 Chronicles 31:15—as well as in
[Biblical Aramaic](/wiki/Biblical_Aramaic "Biblical Aramaic") at verse Ezra
5:2. These Bible verses refer to ten individuals (in Nehemiah 8:17, the name
refers to [Joshua](/wiki/Joshua "Joshua") son of Nun). This historical change
may have been due to a phonological shift whereby guttural phonemes weakened,
including [h].[20] Usually, the traditional theophoric element [Yahu] יהו‬ was
shortened at the beginning of a name to יו‬ [Yo-], and at the end to יה‬
[-yah]. In the contraction of [Yehoshua`] to [Yeshua`], the vowel is instead
fronted (perhaps due to the influence of the _y_ in triliteral root _y-š-ʕ_).
During the post-Biblical period, the name was also adopted by Aramaic and
Greek-speaking Jews.

By the time the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") was
written, the [Septuagint](/wiki/Septuagint "Septuagint") had already
transliterated ישוע [Yeshua`] into [Koine Greek](/wiki/Koine_Greek "Koine
Greek") as closely as possible in the 3rd-century [BCE](/wiki/BCE "BCE"), the
result being Ἰησοῦς [Iēsous]. Since Greek had no equivalent to the Semitic
letter ש‬ _shin_ [sh], it was replaced with a σ _sigma_ [s], and a masculine
singular ending [-s] was added in the nominative case, in order to allow the
name to be inflected for case (nominative, accusative, etc.) in the grammar of
the Greek language. The diphthongal [a] vowel of Masoretic [Yehoshua`] or
[Yeshua`] would not have been present in Hebrew/Aramaic pronunciation during
this period, and some scholars believe some dialects dropped the
[pharyngeal](/wiki/Pharyngeal_consonant "Pharyngeal consonant") sound of the
final letter ע‬ _`ayin_ [`], which in any case had no counterpart in ancient
Greek. The Greek writings of [Philo of Alexandria](/wiki/Philo_of_Alexandria
"Philo of Alexandria")[21] and [Josephus](/wiki/Josephus "Josephus")
frequently mention this name. It also occurs in the Greek New Testament at
Acts 7:45 and Hebrews 4:8, referring to Joshua son of Nun.

From Greek, Ἰησοῦς [Iēsous] moved into [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") at least
by the time of the [Vetus Latina](/wiki/Vetus_Latina "Vetus Latina"). The
morphological jump this time was not as large as previous changes between
language families. Ἰησοῦς [Iēsous] was [transliterated](/wiki/Transliterated
"Transliterated") to Latin _IESVS_ , where it stood for many centuries. The
Latin name has an irregular declension, with a genitive, dative, ablative, and
vocative of _Jesu_ , accusative of _Jesum_ , and nominative of _Jesus_.
[Minuscule](/wiki/Lower_case "Lower case") (lower case) letters were developed
around 800 and some time later the [U](/wiki/U "U") was invented to
distinguish the [vowel](/wiki/Vowel "Vowel") sound from the
[consonantal](/wiki/Consonant "Consonant") sound and the [J](/wiki/J "J") to
distinguish the consonant from [I](/wiki/I "I"). Similarly, Greek minuscules
were invented about the same time, prior to that the name was written in
[Capital letters](/wiki/Capital_letters "Capital letters"): ΙΗϹΟΥϹ or
abbreviated as: ΙΗϹ with a line over the top, see also
[Christogram](/wiki/Christogram "Christogram").

[Modern English](/wiki/Modern_English "Modern English")
"[Jesus](/wiki/Jesus_\(name\) "Jesus \(name\)")"
[/ˈdʒiːzəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") derives from Early
Middle English _Iesu_ (attested from the 12th century). The name participated
in the [Great Vowel Shift](/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift "Great Vowel Shift") in
late [Middle English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English") (15th century).
The letter [J](/wiki/J "J") was first distinguished from 'I' by the Frenchman
[Pierre Ramus](/wiki/Petrus_Ramus "Petrus Ramus") in the 16th century, but did
not become common in Modern English until the 17th century, so that early 17th
century works such as the first edition of the [King James Version of the
Bible](/wiki/King_James_Version_of_the_Bible "King James Version of the
Bible") (1611) continued to print the name with an I.[22]

#### "Jesu"
forms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: "Jesu" forms")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg/40px-Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg.png) | Look up _**[Jesu](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Jesu "wiktionary:Jesu")**_ in Wiktionary, the free dictionary.  
---|---  
  
"Jesu" is a remnant in modern English of the [declension](/wiki/Declension
"Declension") and use of grammatically inflected [case
endings](/wiki/Case_ending "Case ending") with some proper nouns in [Middle
English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English"), which persisted into [Early
Modern English](/wiki/Early_Modern_English "Early Modern English") to around
the time of [Shakespeare](/wiki/Shakespeare "Shakespeare"). The form Jesu is
often a [vocative](/wiki/Vocative "Vocative"), "Jesu!", but may also stand for
other cases, such as [genitive](/wiki/Genitive "Genitive"), as in Latin. The
form "Jesu" was preserved in hymns and poetry long after it had fallen out of
general use in speech, for example in [poet
laureate](/wiki/Poet_Laureate_of_the_United_Kingdom "Poet Laureate of the
United Kingdom") [Robert Bridges](/wiki/Robert_Bridges "Robert Bridges")'
translation of [Johann Schop](/wiki/Johann_Schop "Johann Schop")'s wording for
the English translation of [Johann Sebastian Bach](/wiki/Johann_Sebastian_Bach
"Johann Sebastian Bach")'s cantata, _[Jesu, Joy of Man's
Desiring](/wiki/Jesu,_Joy_of_Man%27s_Desiring "Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring")_
and in T. S. Colvin's hymn, _Jesu, Jesu, fill us with your love_ , based on a
song from northern [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana "Ghana").[23] During the late 19th
Century, as "Jesu" was increasingly seen as antiquated, some churches
attempted to update the wording of hymns containing "Jesu" to "Jesus".[24] In
modernizing hymn texts the use of "Jesu" or "Jesus" could cause problems where
the [metre](/wiki/Metre_\(music\) "Metre \(music\)") only allowed two
[syllables](/wiki/Syllable "Syllable"), "Je-su".[25][_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_]

#### Significance of the
name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Significance of the name")]

See also: [Holy Name of Jesus](/wiki/Holy_Name_of_Jesus "Holy Name of Jesus")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Host%C3%BDn%2C_Bazilika%2C_dve%C5%99e_04.jpg/140px-
Host%C3%BDn%2C_Bazilika%2C_dve%C5%99e_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Host%C3%BDn,_Bazilika,_dve%C5%99e_04.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Host%C3%BDn,_Bazilika,_dve%C5%99e_04.jpg "Enlarge")

The [IHS monogram](/wiki/Christogram#IHS "Christogram") with angels, in
[Hostýn](/wiki/Host%C3%BDn "Hostýn"), Czech Republic.

Christians have attached theological significance to the name of Jesus from
the [earliest days of Christianity](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early
Christianity").[7] Devotions to and feasts for the [Holy Name of
Jesus](/wiki/Holy_Name_of_Jesus "Holy Name of Jesus") exist both in
[Eastern](/wiki/Eastern_Christianity "Eastern Christianity") and [Western
Christianity](/wiki/Western_Church "Western Church").[8] The devotions and
venerations to the name Jesus also extend to the IHS monogram, derived from
the [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") word for Jesus
ΙΗΣΟΥΣ.[9][26][27]

The significance of the name of Jesus in the New Testament is underscored by
the fact that in his [Nativity account](/wiki/Nativity_of_Jesus "Nativity of
Jesus") Matthew pays more attention to the name of the child and its
theological implications than the actual birth event itself.[12][13]

Reverence for the name of Jesus is emphasized by [Saint Paul](/wiki/Saint_Paul
"Saint Paul") in [Philippians
2:10](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Philippians#2:10
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Philippians") where he states: "That
in the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those that are in heaven, on
earth, and under the earth".[9]

The use of the name of Jesus in petitions is stressed in [John
16:23](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#16:23
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") when Jesus states: "If you ask
the Father anything in my name he will give it you." Many Christian prayers
thus conclude with the words: "Through Our Lord Jesus Christ".[9] There is
widespread belief among Christians that the name Jesus is not merely a
sequence of identifying symbols but includes intrinsic divine power, and that
where the name of Jesus is spoken or displayed the power of Jesus can be
called upon.[4][9][10]

###
Emmanuel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Emmanuel")]

Matthew 1:23 ("they shall call his name Emmanuel") provides the name
[Emmanuel](/wiki/Emmanuel "Emmanuel") (meaning _God is with us_).[28]
Emmanuel, which is taken from [Isaiah
7:14](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Isaiah#7:14
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Isaiah"), does not appear elsewhere in
the New Testament.

The name _Emmanuel_ (also _Immanuel_ or _Imanu 'el_) of the Hebrew
_עִמָּנוּאֵל_ "[God](/wiki/Elohim "Elohim") [is] with us" consists of two
[Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew "Hebrew") words: אֵל ([’El](/wiki/El_\(god\) "El
\(god\)"), meaning 'God') and עִמָּנוּ (ʻImmānū, meaning 'with us'); [Standard
Hebrew](/wiki/Standard_Hebrew "Standard Hebrew") _ʻImmanuʼel_ , [Tiberian
Hebrew](/wiki/Tiberian_Hebrew "Tiberian Hebrew") _ʻImmānûʼēl_. It is a
[theophoric](/wiki/Theophoric "Theophoric") name used in the
[Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible") in [Isaiah
7:14](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(King_James\)/Isaiah#7:14 "s:Bible
\(King James\)/Isaiah") and [Isaiah
8:8](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(King_James\)/Isaiah#8:8 "s:Bible
\(King James\)/Isaiah").

Some interpreters see [Matthew
1:23](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#1:23
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") providing a key to an
_Emmanuel Christology_ in the New Testament, with Matthew showing an interest
in identifying Jesus as "God with us" and later developing the Emmanuel theme
at key points throughout his Gospel.[29][30][31] The name Emmanuel does not
directly appear elsewhere in the New Testament, but Matthew builds on the
motif in [Matthew
28:20](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#28:20
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") to indicate that Jesus will
be with the faithful to the end times.[28][31] According to [Ulrich
Luz](/wiki/Ulrich_Luz "Ulrich Luz"), the Emmanuel motif brackets the entire
Gospel of Matthew between 1:23 and 28:20, appearing explicitly and implicitly
in several other passages, setting the tone for the salvific theme of
Matthew.[32] Some Christians see the same meaning in [Matthew
28:20](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#28:20
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") ("I am with you always, even
unto the end of the world") indicates that Jesus will be with the faithful to
the end of the age.[28]

##
Titles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Titles")]

###
Christ[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Christ")]

Main article: [Christ (title)](/wiki/Christ_\(title\) "Christ \(title\)")

See also: [Confession of Peter](/wiki/Confession_of_Peter "Confession of
Peter")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Istanbul.Hagia_Sophia072.Jesus.jpg/130px-
Istanbul.Hagia_Sophia072.Jesus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Istanbul.Hagia_Sophia072.Jesus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Istanbul.Hagia_Sophia072.Jesus.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mosaic](/wiki/Mosaic "Mosaic") of [Christ
Pantocrator](/wiki/Christ_Pantocrator "Christ Pantocrator") with the
[Christogram IC XC](/wiki/Christogram "Christogram").

The title [Christ](/wiki/Christ_\(title\) "Christ \(title\)") used in the
English language is from the [Greek](/wiki/Koine_Greek "Koine Greek") Χριστός
(_Kristos_), via the [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") _Christus_. It means
"[anointed one](/wiki/Anointing "Anointing")".[33] The Greek is a loan
translation of the Hebrew _mashiaħ_ (מָשִׁיחַ) or Aramaic _mshiħa_
(מְשִׁיחָא), from which we derive the English word [Messiah](/wiki/Messiah
"Messiah"). Christ has now become a name, one part of the name "Jesus Christ",
but originally it was a title (the Messiah) and not a name; however its use in
"Christ Jesus" is a title.[34][35][36]

In the [Septuagint](/wiki/Septuagint "Septuagint") version of the [Hebrew
Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible") (written over a century before the
time of Jesus), the word _Christos_ was used to translate into Greek the
[Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_\(language\) "Hebrew \(language\)") _mashiach_
(messiah), meaning "anointed."[37][38] (Another Greek word, _Messias_ appears
in Daniel 9:26 and Psalm 2:2.[39][40]) The [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament
"New Testament") states that the Messiah, long-awaited, had come and describes
this savior as _The Christ._ In [Matthew
16:16](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#16:16
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") Apostle Peter, in what has
become a famous proclamation of faith among Christians since the first
century, said, "You are the Christ, the Son of the living God."[41] In [John
11:27](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#11:27
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") Martha tells Jesus "you are the
Christ", just before the [Raising of Lazarus](/wiki/Raising_of_Lazarus
"Raising of Lazarus").[42]

In the [Pauline Epistles](/wiki/Pauline_Epistles "Pauline Epistles") the word
Christ is so closely associated with Jesus that it is apparent that for the
early Christians there is no need to claim that Jesus is Christ, for that is
considered widely accepted among them. Hence Paul can use the term _Christos_
with no confusion as to whom it refers to, and as in [First Corinthians
4:15](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1Corinthians#4:15
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1Corinthians") and [Romans
12:5](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Romans#12:5
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Romans") he can use expressions such
as "in Christ" to refer to the followers of Jesus.[43]

Symbols for representing Christ (i.e. [Christograms](/wiki/Christogram
"Christogram")) were developed by early Christians, e.g. the _[Chi
Rho](/wiki/Chi_Rho "Chi Rho")_ symbol formed by superimposing the first two
Greek letters in Christ ( [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") :
"Χριστός" ), [chi](/wiki/Chi_\(letter\) "Chi \(letter\)") = ch and
[rho](/wiki/Rho_\(letter\) "Rho \(letter\)") = r, to produce ☧.[44]

###
Lord[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Lord")]

See also: [Jesus is Lord](/wiki/Jesus_is_Lord "Jesus is Lord"),
[Christology](/wiki/Christology "Christology"), and [Kyrios](/wiki/Kyrios
"Kyrios")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Christogram_with_Jesus_Prayer_in_Romanian.jpg/130px-
Christogram_with_Jesus_Prayer_in_Romanian.jpg)](/wiki/File:Christogram_with_Jesus_Prayer_in_Romanian.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Christogram_with_Jesus_Prayer_in_Romanian.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Chi Rho](/wiki/Chi_Rho "Chi Rho") circled with the Prayer: "_Lord Jesus
Christ, Son of God, have mercy on me_ ".

Early Christians viewed Jesus as "the Lord" and the Greek word
_[Kyrios](/wiki/Kyrios "Kyrios")_ (κύριος) which may mean [God](/wiki/God
"God"), [lord](/wiki/Lord "Lord") or master appears over 700 times in the [New
Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament"), referring to him.[45][46] In
everyday [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic "Aramaic"), _Mari_ was a very respectful form
of polite address, well above "Teacher" and similar to [Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi
"Rabbi"). In Greek this has at times been translated as Kyrios. While the term
Mari expressed the relationship between Jesus and his disciples during his
life, the Greek Kyrios came to represent his lordship over the world.[47]

[Pauline writings](/wiki/Pauline_Christianity "Pauline Christianity") further
established the various theological consequences of the Lord/Kyrios concept
among early Christians, and emphasized the attributes of Jesus as not only
referring to his eschatological victory, but to him as the "divine image"
([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") εἰκών _eikōn_) in whose face
the glory of God shines forth.[48] In [Romans
10:9–13](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Romans#10:9
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Romans") Paul emphasized the
[salvific](/wiki/Salvation_in_Christianity "Salvation in Christianity") value
of the title, and stated that confessing by mouth (_homologeo_) the belief
that Jesus is Lord (_Kyrion Iesoun_) signifies one's salvation.[49]

The high frequency of the use of the term Kyrios in the [Acts of the
Apostles](/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles "Acts of the Apostles") indicates how
natural it was for [early Christians](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early
Christianity") to refer to Jesus in this way.[45] This title persisted among
Christians as the predominant perception of Jesus for a number of
centuries.[48]

The use of the _Kyrios title_ for Jesus is central to the development of New
Testament [Christology](/wiki/Christology "Christology"), for the early
Christians placed it at the center of their understanding and from that center
attempted to understand the other issues related to the Christian
mysteries.[50] The question of the deity of Christ in the New Testament is
inherently related to the Kyrios title of Jesus used in the early Christian
writings and its implications for the absolute lordship of Jesus. In early
Christian belief, the concept of Kyrios included the [Pre-existence of
Christ](/wiki/Pre-existence_of_Christ "Pre-existence of Christ") for they
believed that if Christ is one with God, he must have been united with God
from the very beginning.[46][50]

The title, even in the Greek form, continues to be widely used in Christian
[liturgy](/wiki/Liturgy "Liturgy"), e.g. in the [Kyrie](/wiki/Kyrie "Kyrie")
eleison, Christe eleison combination (i.e. _Lord have mercy_ , _Christ have
mercy_), where Jesus is referred to as Lord in one case, and as
[Christ](/wiki/Christ "Christ") immediately thereafter.[51]

###
Master[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Master")]

The Greek word _[Epistates](/wiki/Epistates "Epistates")_ (_Epistata_ in the
[vocative case](/wiki/Vocative_case "Vocative case")) is used only in Luke's
gospel, where it occurs six times. Robert O'Toole argues that the word relates
to Jesus power over the material world rather than his teaching.[52] Some
commentators suggest that in [Luke 5](/wiki/Luke_5 "Luke 5"), Peter progresses
from seeing Jesus as "Master" (v. 5) to seeing him as "Lord" (v. 8).[53]

### Logos (the
Word)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Logos \(the Word\)")]

Main articles: [Logos (Christianity)](/wiki/Logos_\(Christianity\) "Logos
\(Christianity\)"), [Pre-existence of Christ](/wiki/Pre-existence_of_Christ
"Pre-existence of Christ"), [Person of Christ](/wiki/Person_of_Christ "Person
of Christ"), and [Hypostatic union](/wiki/Hypostatic_union "Hypostatic union")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Prologus_Ioanni_Vulgata_Clementina.jpg/180px-
Prologus_Ioanni_Vulgata_Clementina.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prologus_Ioanni_Vulgata_Clementina.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Prologus_Ioanni_Vulgata_Clementina.jpg "Enlarge")

_In principio erat verbum_ , [Latin](/wiki/Latin_\(language\) "Latin
\(language\)") for _At the beginning there was the Word_. John 1:1-18 from the
[Clementine Vulgate](/wiki/Sixto-Clementine_Vulgate "Sixto-Clementine
Vulgate").

[John
1:1-18](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#1:1-18
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") calls Jesus the
_[Logos](/wiki/Logos_\(Christianity\) "Logos \(Christianity\)")_ (Greek
[λόγος](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BB%CF%8C%CE%B3%CE%BF%CF%82
"wiktionary:λόγος")), often used as "the Word" in English translations.[54]
The identification of Jesus as the Logos which became
[Incarnate](/wiki/Incarnation "Incarnation") appears only at the beginning of
the [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") and the term
Logos/Word is used only in two other [Johannine](/wiki/Johannine "Johannine")
passages: [1 John
1:1](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_John#1:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 John") and [Revelation
19:13](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#19:13
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation"). It appears nowhere else
in the New Testament.[55][56][57][58]

The series of statements regarding the Logos at the very beginning of the
[Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") build on each
other.[59] The statement that the Logos existed "at the beginning" asserts
that as Logos Jesus was an eternal being like God. The statement that the
Logos was "with God" asserts the distinction of Jesus from God. The statement
that the Logos "was God" states the unity of Jesus with God, thus stating his
divinity.[56][59]

In [1 John
1:1](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_John#1:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 John") the arrival of the Logos as
"the Word of life" from the beginning is emphasized and [1 John
5:6](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_John#5:6
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 John") builds on it to emphasize the
water and blood of incarnation.[56] With the use of the title Logos, Johannine
[Christology](/wiki/Christology "Christology") consciously affirms the belief
in the divinity of Jesus: that he was God who came to be among men as the Word
Incarnate.[56][58][60]

Although as of the 2nd century the use of the title Logos gave rise to debate
between the Alexandrian and Antiochian schools of thought regarding the
interaction of the human and divine elements in the [Person of
Christ](/wiki/Person_of_Christ "Person of Christ"), after the [First Council
of Nicaea](/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea "First Council of Nicaea") in 325 and
[Council of Chalcedon](/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon "Council of Chalcedon") in
451 the Logos and the second person of the [Trinity](/wiki/Holy_Trinity "Holy
Trinity") were often used interchangeably.[58][61][62][63]

### Son of
God[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Son of God")]

Main article: [Son of God (Christianity)](/wiki/Son_of_God_\(Christianity\)
"Son of God \(Christianity\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Sargis_Pitsak.jpg/130px-
Sargis_Pitsak.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sargis_Pitsak.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sargis_Pitsak.jpg "Enlarge")

First page of [Mark](/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark "Gospel of Mark"): "_The beginning
of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God_ ", by [Sargis
Pitsak](/wiki/Sargis_Pitsak "Sargis Pitsak") 14th century.

The title "Son of God" is applied to Jesus in many cases in the New
Testament.[64] It is often used to refer to his divinity, from the beginning
in the [Annunciation](/wiki/Annunciation "Annunciation") up to the
[Crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus "Crucifixion of Jesus").[64] The
declaration that Jesus is the Son of God is made by many individuals in the
New Testament, on two separate occasions by [God the
Father](/wiki/God_the_Father "God the Father") as a voice from Heaven, and is
also asserted by Jesus himself.[64][65][66][67] The Son of God title,
according to most [Christian denominations](/wiki/Christian_denominations
"Christian denominations"), [Trinitarian](/wiki/Trinitarianism
"Trinitarianism") in belief, refers to the relationship between
[Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") and [God](/wiki/God "God"), specifically as "[God
the Son](/wiki/God_the_Son "God the Son")".[65][67]

For thousands of years, emperors and rulers ranging from the [Western Zhou
dynasty](/wiki/Western_Zhou_dynasty "Western Zhou dynasty") (c. 1000 B.C.) in
China to [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the
Great") in Greece have assumed titles that reflect a filial relationship with
[deities](/wiki/Deity "Deity").[68][69] At the time of Jesus, Roman Emperor
[Augustus](/wiki/Augustus "Augustus") exploited the similarity between the
titles [Divi filius](/wiki/Divi_filius "Divi filius") (son of the Divine One)
and "Dei filius" (Son of God) and used the ambiguous inscription "DF" to refer
to himself to emphasize the divine component of his image.[70][71][72][73] [J.
D. Crossan](/wiki/John_Dominic_Crossan "John Dominic Crossan") argues that
early Christians adopted this title.[74]

The [Gospel of Mark](/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark "Gospel of Mark") begins by calling
Jesus the Son of God and reaffirms the title twice when a voice from Heaven
calls Jesus: "my Son" in Mark 1:11 and Mark 9:7.[75] In Matthew 14:33, after
[Jesus walks on water](/wiki/Jesus_walks_on_water "Jesus walks on water"), the
disciples tell Jesus: "You really are the Son of God!"[66] In [Matthew
27:43](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#27:43
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew"), while Jesus hangs on the
cross, the Jewish leaders [mock him](/wiki/Mocking_of_Jesus "Mocking of
Jesus") to ask God help, "for he said, I am the Son of God", referring to the
claim of Jesus to be the Son of God.[67] Matthew 27:54 and Mark 15:39 include
the exclamation by the Roman commander, "He was surely the Son of God!", after
the earthquake following the [Crucifixion of Jesus](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus
"Crucifixion of Jesus"). When, in Matthew 16:15–16, [Apostle
Peter](/wiki/Apostle_Peter "Apostle Peter") states, "You are Christ, the Son
of the living God", Jesus not only accepts the titles, but calls Peter
"blessed" and declares the profession a divine revelation, unequivocally
declaring himself to be both Christ and the Son of God in [Matthew
16:15-16](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#16:15
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew").[65][65]

In the new Testament, Jesus uses the term "my Father" as a direct and
unequivocal assertion of his sonship, and a unique relationship with the
Father beyond any attribution of titles by others, e.g., in [Matthew
11:27](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#11:27
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew"), [John
5:23](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#5:23
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") and [John
5:26](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#5:26
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John").[67][76][77] In a number of
other episodes, Jesus claims sonship by referring to the Father, e.g., in Luke
2:49, when he is [found in the temple](/wiki/Finding_in_the_Temple "Finding in
the Temple"), a young Jesus calls the temple "my Father's house", just as he
does later in John 2:16 in the [Cleansing of the
Temple](/wiki/Cleansing_of_the_Temple "Cleansing of the Temple") episode.[67]
In Matthew 1:11 and Luke 3:22, Jesus allows himself to be called the Son of
God by the voice from above, not objecting to the title.[67]

Of all the [Christological](/wiki/Christology "Christology") titles used in
the New Testament, Son of God has had one of the most lasting impacts in
Christian history and has become part of the profession of faith by many
Christians.[78] In the mainstream [Trinitarian](/wiki/Trinitarianism
"Trinitarianism") context, the title implies the full divinity of Jesus as
part of the [Holy Trinity](/wiki/Holy_Trinity "Holy Trinity") of
[Father](/wiki/God_the_Father "God the Father"), Son and the
[Spirit](/wiki/Holy_Spirit "Holy Spirit").[78] However, the concept of God as
the father of Jesus and Jesus as the one and only Son of God is distinct from
the concept of God as the Creator and father of all people, as indicated in
the [Apostle's Creed](/wiki/Apostle%27s_Creed "Apostle's Creed").[79] The
profession begins with expressing belief in the "Father almighty, creator of
heaven and earth" and then immediately, but separately, in "Jesus Christ, his
only Son, our Lord", thus expressing both senses of fatherhood within the
Creed.[79]

### Son of
Man[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Son of Man")]

Main article: [Son of man (Christianity)](/wiki/Son_of_man_\(Christianity\)
"Son of man \(Christianity\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/BL_Harley_Gospels_109r.jpg/130px-
BL_Harley_Gospels_109r.jpg)](/wiki/File:BL_Harley_Gospels_109r.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:BL_Harley_Gospels_109r.jpg "Enlarge")

"Son of man" appears 25 times in [Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke "Gospel of
Luke"), a [copy c. 800](/wiki/Harley_Golden_Gospels "Harley Golden Gospels")
shown here.[80]

The term Son of man appears many times in all four gospel accounts, e.g. 30
times in Matthew.[80] However, unlike the title [Son of God](/wiki/Son_of_God
"Son of God"), its proclamation has never been an article of faith in
Christianity.[81] While the profession of Jesus as the Son of God has been an
essential element of Christian creeds since the [Apostolic
age](/wiki/Apostolic_age "Apostolic age"), such professions do not apply to
Son of man. Yet, the [Christological](/wiki/Christology "Christology")
analysis of the relationship between the two terms has been the subject of
much research.[81]

In modern biblical research the occurrences of Son of man in the [Synoptic
gospels](/wiki/Synoptic_gospel "Synoptic gospel") are generally categorized
into three groups: those that refer to his "coming" (as an exaltation), those
that refer to "suffering" and those that refer to "now at work", i.e.
referring to the earthly life.[80][82][83]

The presentation in the [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of
John") is somewhat different from the Synoptics and in John 1:51 he is
presented as contact with God through "angelic instrumentality", in John 6:26
and 6:53 he provides life through his death and in John 5:27 he holds the
power to judge men.[80] The first chapter of the [Book of
Revelation](/wiki/Book_of_Revelation "Book of Revelation") refers to "one like
a Son of man" in [Revelation
1:12–13](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#1:12
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation") which radiantly stands in
glory and speaks to the author.[84] In the Gospel of John Jesus is not just a
[messianic](/wiki/Messiah "Messiah") figure, nor a prophet like Moses, but the
key emphasis is on his dual role as [Son of God](/wiki/Son_of_God "Son of
God") and [Son of man](/wiki/Son_of_man "Son of man").[85]

Although Son of man is a distinct from Son of God, some gospel passages equate
them in some cases, e.g. in [Mark
14:61](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#14:61
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark"), during the [Sanhedrin trial of
Jesus](/wiki/Sanhedrin_trial_of_Jesus "Sanhedrin trial of Jesus") when the
high priest asked Jesus: "Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed one?"
Jesus responded "I am: and you shall see the Son of man sitting at the right
hand of Power, and coming with the clouds of heaven.".[83][86] This builds on
the statement in [Mark
9:31](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#9:31
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark") that "The Son of man is
delivered up into the hands of men, and they shall kill him; and when he is
killed, after three days he shall rise again."[83] In the parable of [the
Sheep and the Goats](/wiki/The_Sheep_and_the_Goats "The Sheep and the Goats"),
the returning Son of man has the power to judge, by separating men from "all
the nations" into distinct groups, in Matthew 25:31–46.[83]

For centuries, the Christological perspective on Son of man has been a natural
counterpart to that of Son of God and in many cases affirms the humanity of
Jesus just as Son of God affirms his divinity.[82] In the 5th century, [Saint
Augustine](/wiki/Saint_Augustine "Saint Augustine") viewed the duality of Son
of God and Son of man in terms of the dual nature of Christ in [hypostatic
union](/wiki/Hypostatic_union "Hypostatic union"), in that the Son of God
became the Son of man through the act of [Incarnation](/wiki/Incarnation
"Incarnation") and wrote: "Since he is the only Son of God by nature, he
became also the Son of Man that he might be full of grace as well."[87][88]

[Geza Vermes](/wiki/Geza_Vermes "Geza Vermes") has argued that "the son of
man" in the Gospels is unrelated to these [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible
"Hebrew Bible") usages. He begins with the observation that there is no
example of "the" son of man in Hebrew sources. He suggests that the term
originates in [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic_language "Aramaic language")— _bar
nash/bar nasha_. Based on his study of Aramaic sources, he concludes that in
these sources: (1) "Son of man" is a regular expression for _man_ in general.
(2) It often serves as an indefinite pronoun ("one" or "someone"). (3) In
certain circumstances it may be employed as a
[circumlocution](/wiki/Circumlocution "Circumlocution"). In monologues or
dialogues the speaker can refer to himself, not as 'I', but as "the son of
man" in the third person, in contexts implying awe, reserve, or modesty. (4)
In none of the extant texts does "son of man" figure as a title.[89]

### Son of
David[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Son of David")]

The title "Son of David" indicates Jesus' physical descent from
[David](/wiki/David "David"), as well as his membership of the [Davidic
line](/wiki/Davidic_line "Davidic line") of kings. The phrase is used a number
of times in the [gospel of Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew "Gospel of
Matthew"). It appears in [Matthew 1:1](/wiki/Matthew_1:1 "Matthew 1:1") to
introduce both the [genealogy](/wiki/Genealogy_of_Jesus "Genealogy of Jesus")
and the gospel. It is found on the lips of the [blind men healed in
Galilee](/wiki/Healing_the_two_blind_men_in_Galilee "Healing the two blind men
in Galilee") ("Have mercy on us, Son of David", [Matthew
9:27](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%209:27–9:27&version=nkjv)),
the crowd who are amazed at Jesus' healing of a blind, mute and demon-
possessed man [Matthew
12:23](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2012:23–12:23&version=nkjv)),
the [Canaanite woman whose daughter is
exorcised](/wiki/Exorcising_the_Canaanite_woman%27s_daughter "Exorcising the
Canaanite woman's daughter") ("Lord, Son of David, have mercy on me," [Matthew
15:22](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2015:22–15:22&version=nkjv)),
and the [blind men healed near Jericho](/wiki/Healing_the_blind_near_Jericho
"Healing the blind near Jericho") ("Lord, Son of David, have mercy on us",
[Matthew
20:30](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2020:30–20:30&version=nkjv)).
Finally, it also forms part of the shout of the crowds when [Jesus enters
Jerusalem](/wiki/Triumphal_entry_into_Jerusalem "Triumphal entry into
Jerusalem"): "Hosanna to the Son of David" (Matthew 21:9).

A variant of this title is found in [Revelation
22:16](http://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Revelation+22:16–22:16&version=nrsv),
where Jesus refers to himself as "the Root and the Offspring of David".

According to Anglican Bishop [Charles Ellicott](/wiki/Charles_Ellicott
"Charles Ellicott"), "Son of David" was "the most popular of all the names of
the expected Christ".[90]

### Lamb of
God[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Lamb of God")]

Main article: [Lamb of God](/wiki/Lamb_of_God "Lamb of God")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Agnus_Dei_with_Vexillum.jpg/140px-
Agnus_Dei_with_Vexillum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Agnus_Dei_with_Vexillum.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Agnus_Dei_with_Vexillum.jpg "Enlarge")

A typical depiction of [Agnus Dei](/wiki/Agnus_Dei "Agnus Dei"), bleeding into
a [Holy Chalice](/wiki/Holy_Chalice "Holy Chalice") and carrying a Christian
victory banner.

The title _Lamb of God_ ([Agnus Dei](/wiki/Agnus_Dei "Agnus Dei")) only
appears in the [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John"), with
the exclamation of [John the Baptist](/wiki/John_the_Baptist "John the
Baptist"): "Behold the Lamb of God who takes away the sins of the world" in
[John
1:29](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#1:29
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"), the title reaffirmed the next
day in [John
1:36](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#1:36
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John").[91] The second use of the
title Lamb of God takes place in the presence of the first two
[apostles](/wiki/Twelve_apostles "Twelve apostles") of Jesus, who immediately
follow him, address him as [Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi") with respect and later
in the narrative bring others to meet him.[92]

These two proclamations of Jesus as the Lamb of God closely bracket the
Baptist's other proclamation in [John
1:34](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#1:34
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"): "I have borne witness that
this is the Son of God". From a [Christological](/wiki/Christology
"Christology") perspective, these proclamations and the descent of the [Holy
Spirit](/wiki/Holy_Spirit "Holy Spirit") as a dove in John 1:32 reinforce each
other to establish the divine element of the [Person of
Christ](/wiki/Person_of_Christ "Person of Christ").[91] In Johannine
Christology the proclamation "who takes away the sins of the world" begins the
unfolding of the [salvific](/wiki/Salvation_in_Christianity "Salvation in
Christianity") theme of the redemptive and sacrificial death of Jesus followed
by his resurrection which is built upon in other proclamations such as "this
is indeed the Saviour of the world" uttered by the Samaritans in [John
4:42](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#4:42
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John").[93][94] However, nothing in
the context of [1 Corinthians
5:7](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_Corinthians#5:7
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 Corinthians") directly implies that
in that specific passage [Saint Paul](/wiki/Saint_Paul "Saint Paul") refers
the death of Jesus using the same theme.[95]

The [Book of Revelation](/wiki/Book_of_Revelation "Book of Revelation")
includes over twenty references to a lion-like lamb ("slain but standing")
which delivers victory in a manner reminiscent of the resurrected Christ.[96]
In the first appearance of the lamb in Revelation
([5:1-7](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#5:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation")) only the lamb (which is
of the tribe of Judah, and the root of David) is found worthy to take the
judgment scroll from God and break the seals. In [Revelation
21:14](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#21:14
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation") the lamb is said to have
twelve apostles.[96]

The theme of a sacrificial lamb which rises in victory as the [Resurrected
Christ](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus "Resurrection of Jesus") was employed in
early Christology, e.g. in 375 [Saint Augustine](/wiki/Saint_Augustine "Saint
Augustine") wrote: "Why a lamb in his passion? For he underwent death without
being guilty of any inequity. Why a lion in his resurrection? For in being
slain, he slew death."[97] The Lamb of God title has found widespread use in
Christian prayers and the _Agnus Dei_ ("Lamb of God who take away the sins of
the world have mercy on us; Lamb of God who take away the sins of the world
grant us peace") is used both in [liturgy](/wiki/Liturgy "Liturgy") and as a
form of [contemplative prayer](/wiki/Contemplative_prayer "Contemplative
prayer").[98][99]

### New Adam / Second Adam / Last
Adam[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: New Adam / Second Adam / Last Adam")]

Main article: [Last Adam](/wiki/Last_Adam "Last Adam")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Kariye_ic.jpg/200px-
Kariye_ic.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kariye_ic.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kariye_ic.jpg "Enlarge")

The Resurrected Jesus pulls [Adam and Eve](/wiki/Adam_and_Eve "Adam and Eve")
out of their graves, with Satan bound in Hell, [Chora
Church](/wiki/Chora_Church "Chora Church"), Istanbul, c. 1315.

> Just as in Adam all of us died, so too in Christ all of us will be brought
> to life.
>
> — [1 Corinthians
> 15:22](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_Corinthians#15:22
> "wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 Corinthians")

Just as the [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") proclaims
the universal relevance of the Incarnation of Jesus as [Logos](/wiki/Logos
"Logos"), the Pauline view emphasizes the cosmic view that his birth,
[Crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus "Crucifixion of Jesus") and
[Resurrection](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus "Resurrection of Jesus") brought
forth a new man and a [new world](/wiki/World_to_Come "World to Come").[34]
Paul's [eschatological](/wiki/Eschatology "Eschatology") view of Jesus
counter-positions him as a new man of morality and obedience, in contrast to
[Adam](/wiki/Adam "Adam"). Unlike Adam, the new man born in Jesus obeys God
and ushers in a world of morality and salvation.[100]

In the Pauline view, Adam is positioned as the first man and Jesus as the
second and last Adam ([1 Corinthians
15:45](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_Corinthians#15:45
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 Corinthians")), the first having
corrupted himself by his disobedience, also infected humanity and left it with
a curse as inheritance. The birth of Jesus, on the other hand, counterbalanced
the fall of Adam, bringing forth redemption and repairing the damage done by
Adam.[101]

The theme is reiterated by Paul, in [Romans
5:18-21](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Romans#5:18
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Romans"), when he states:

> Therefore just as one man's trespass led to condemnation for all, so one
> man's act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all. For just
> as by the one man's disobedience the many were made sinners, so by the one
> man's obedience the many will be made righteous. But law came in, with the
> result that the trespass multiplied; but where sin increased, grace abounded
> all the more, so that, just as sin exercised dominion in death, so grace
> might also exercise dominion through justification* leading to eternal life
> through Jesus Christ our Lord.

In the 2nd century [Church Father](/wiki/Church_Father "Church Father")
[Irenaeus](/wiki/Irenaeus "Irenaeus") continued this tradition and stated: "so
that what we had lost in Adam - namely to be according to the image and
likeness of God- that we might recover in Christ Jesus."[102][103] Irenaeus
also used the analogy of "second Adam and second Eve" and suggested the Virgin
Mary as the "second Eve" who had set a path of obedience for the second Adam
(i.e. Jesus) from the [Annunciation](/wiki/Annunciation "Annunciation") to
[Calvary](/wiki/Calvary "Calvary").[104]

The tradition continued in the 4th century by [Ephrem the
Syrian](/wiki/Ephrem_the_Syrian "Ephrem the Syrian") and later by [Saint
Augustine](/wiki/Saint_Augustine "Saint Augustine") in his _[Felix
culpa](/wiki/Felix_culpa "Felix culpa")_ , i.e. the happy fall from grace of
[Adam and Eve](/wiki/Adam_and_Eve "Adam and Eve").[105][106] Later, in the
16th century, [John Calvin](/wiki/John_Calvin "John Calvin") viewed the birth
of Jesus as the second Adam one of the six modes of atonement.[107]

### Light of the
World[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Light of the World")]

Main article: [Light of the World](/wiki/Light_of_the_World "Light of the
World")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Bantry_Church_of_St._Brendan_The_Navigator_Third_North_Window_I_am_the_Light_of_the_World_Detail_2009_09_09.jpg/140px-
Bantry_Church_of_St._Brendan_The_Navigator_Third_North_Window_I_am_the_Light_of_the_World_Detail_2009_09_09.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bantry_Church_of_St._Brendan_The_Navigator_Third_North_Window_I_am_the_Light_of_the_World_Detail_2009_09_09.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bantry_Church_of_St._Brendan_The_Navigator_Third_North_Window_I_am_the_Light_of_the_World_Detail_2009_09_09.jpg
"Enlarge")

Stained glass of Jesus as "Light of the World", Church of [St.
Brendan](/wiki/St._Brendan_the_Navigator "St. Brendan the Navigator"),
[Bantry](/wiki/Bantry "Bantry"), Ireland.

Jesus is called a light in seven instances in the New Testament and [Light of
the World](/wiki/Light_of_the_World "Light of the World") only in the Gospel
of John. The terms "Bread of Life" and "Life of the World" are also applied by
Jesus to himself in John's Gospel in the same
[Christological](/wiki/Christology "Christology") sense.[108]

In [John
8:12](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#8:12
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") Jesus applies the title to
himself while debating with the Jews, and states:[109]

    I am the light of the world: he who follows me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.

Jesus again claims to be Light of the World in [John
9:5](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#9:5
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"), during the miracle of [healing
the blind at birth](/wiki/Healing_the_blind_at_birth "Healing the blind at
birth"), saying: [108]

    When I am in the world, I am the Light of the World.

This episode leads into [John
9:39](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#9:39
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") where Jesus metaphorically
explains that he came to this world, so that the blind may see.[108]

In the Christological context, the use of the title "Light of the World" is
similar to the use of the title "[Bread of Life](/wiki/Bread_of_Life "Bread of
Life")" in [John
6:35](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#6:35
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"), where Jesus states: "I am the
bread of life: he who comes to me shall not hunger.[110] These assertions
build on the Christological theme of [John
5:26](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#5:26
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") where Jesus claims to possess
life Just as the Father does and provide it to those who follow him.[76][110]
The term "Life of the World" is applied in the same sense by Jesus to himself
in [John
6:51](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#6:51
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John").[108]

This application of "light compared with darkness" also appears in [1 John
1:5](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_John#1:5
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 John") which applies it to God and
states: "God is light, and in him is no darkness at all."[111]

Jesus also used the term Light of the World to refer to his disciples, in
[Matthew
5:14](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#5:14
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew"):[109] The term "Light of the
World" is related to the parables of [Salt and Light](/wiki/Salt_and_Light
"Salt and Light") and [Lamp under a bushel](/wiki/Lamp_under_a_bushel "Lamp
under a bushel").

### King of the
Jews[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: King of the Jews")]

Main articles: [Jesus, King of the Jews](/wiki/Jesus,_King_of_the_Jews "Jesus,
King of the Jews") and [INRI](/wiki/INRI "INRI")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Ellwangen_St_Vitus_Vorhalle_Kreuzaltar_detail2.jpg/220px-
Ellwangen_St_Vitus_Vorhalle_Kreuzaltar_detail2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ellwangen_St_Vitus_Vorhalle_Kreuzaltar_detail2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ellwangen_St_Vitus_Vorhalle_Kreuzaltar_detail2.jpg "Enlarge")

The acronym [INRI](/wiki/INRI "INRI") (Jesus of Nazareth, [King of the
Jews](/wiki/Jesus,_King_of_the_Jews "Jesus, King of the Jews")) written in
three languages, as in [John
19:20](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#19:20
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"),[112] [Ellwangen
Abbey](/wiki/Ellwangen_Abbey "Ellwangen Abbey"), Germany.

In the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament"), Jesus is referred
to as the _[King of the Jews](/wiki/Jesus,_King_of_the_Jews "Jesus, King of
the Jews")_ on three occasions, coming at the beginning of his life and at the
end. Both uses of the title lead to dramatic results in the New Testament
accounts. In the account of the [Nativity of Jesus](/wiki/Nativity_of_Jesus
"Nativity of Jesus") in the [Gospel of Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew
"Gospel of Matthew"), wise men (called the [Magi](/wiki/Biblical_Magi
"Biblical Magi")) who come from the east call Jesus the "King of the Jews",
causing [King Herod](/wiki/Herod_the_Great "Herod the Great") to order the
[Massacre of the Innocents](/wiki/Massacre_of_the_Innocents "Massacre of the
Innocents"). In the accounts of the [Passion of
Jesus](/wiki/Passion_\(Christianity\) "Passion \(Christianity\)") in all four
[Canonical Gospels](/wiki/Canonical_Gospel "Canonical Gospel"), the use of the
"King of the Jews" title leads to charges against Jesus that result in [his
Crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus "Crucifixion of Jesus").[113][114]

The title "King of the Jews" is used only by the gentiles, namely by the
[Magi](/wiki/Biblical_Magi "Biblical Magi"), [Pontius
Pilate](/wiki/Pontius_Pilate "Pontius Pilate") and the Roman soldiers. In
contrast the Jewish leaders in the Passion accounts prefer the designation
"King of Israel", as in [Matthew
27:42](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#27:42
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew"), [Mark
15:32](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#15:32
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark"). The use of the term "King" in
the charges brought against Jesus is central in the decision to crucify
him.[114] In [John
19:12](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#19:12
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") Pilate seeks to release Jesus,
but the Jews object, saying: "If thou release this man, thou art not Caesar's
friend: every one that maketh himself a king speaketh against Caesar" bringing
the power of Caesar to the forefront of the discussion for the assumption of
the title King implies rebellion against the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire
"Roman Empire")[113][114]

The final use of the title only appears in [Luke
23:36-37](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Luke#23:36
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Luke"). Here, after Jesus has carried
the cross to [Calvary](/wiki/Calvary "Calvary") and has been nailed to the
cross, the soldiers look up on him on the cross, [mock
him](/wiki/Mocking_of_Jesus "Mocking of Jesus"), offer him vinegar and say:
"If thou art the King of the Jews, save thyself." In the parallel account in
[Matthew
27:42](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#27:42
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") the Jewish priests mock
Jesus as "King of Israel", saying: "He is the King of Israel; let him now come
down from the cross, and we will believe on him."[113][115]

### Rabboni and
Rabbi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Rabboni and Rabbi")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Correggio_Noli_Me_Tangere.jpg/220px-
Correggio_Noli_Me_Tangere.jpg)](/wiki/File:Correggio_Noli_Me_Tangere.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Correggio_Noli_Me_Tangere.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mary Magdalene](/wiki/Mary_Magdalene "Mary Magdalene") calling Jesus
_Rabboni_ and receiving the response: _[Noli me Tangere](/wiki/Noli_me_Tangere
"Noli me Tangere")_ , depicted by [Antonio da
Correggio](/wiki/Antonio_da_Correggio "Antonio da Correggio"), circa 1534.

In [John
20:16](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#20:16
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"), when [Mary
Magdalene](/wiki/Mary_Magdalene "Mary Magdalene") encounters Jesus shortly
after [the Resurrection](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus "Resurrection of Jesus"),
she calls him [Rabbouni](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi") (_ῥαββουνί_) literally _my great
[one]_ or (more extensively) _my Teacher_.[116] For those who do not speak
[Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic_of_Jesus "Aramaic of Jesus") the [Gospel of
John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") translates this as "teacher", a
[Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi") being a Jewish teacher, or master.[117] In the
New Testament, the term _Rhabbouni_ is only used by the Magdalene here in John
20:16 and in [Mark
10:51](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#10:51
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark") by the blind man Bartimaeus in
the account of the miracle of [healing the blind near
Jericho](/wiki/Healing_the_blind_near_Jericho "Healing the blind near
Jericho").[118]

The [Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi") title is used in several New Testament
episodes to refer to Jesus, but more often in the [Gospel of
John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") than elsewhere and does not
appear in the [Gospel of Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke "Gospel of Luke") at
all.[119] In Matthew's account of the [Last Supper](/wiki/Last_Supper "Last
Supper") ([Matthew
26:22-25](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#26:22
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew")) when Jesus says that he
will be betrayed by one of his Apostles, one after another the Apostles say
"Surely it is not I, Lord" but [Judas Iscariot](/wiki/Judas_Iscariot "Judas
Iscariot") says "Surely it is not I, Rabbi", using the term Rabbi instead of
Lord.[120] The Iscariot again calls Jesus Rabbi in [Matthew
26:49](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#26:49
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") when he betrays him in the
[Kiss of Judas](/wiki/Kiss_of_Judas "Kiss of Judas") episode, heavily implying
he may never have acknowledged, believed, or understood the divinity of Jesus.

Jesus is called Rabbi in conversation by [Apostle Peter](/wiki/Apostle_Peter
"Apostle Peter") in [Mark
9:5](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#9:5
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark") and [Mark
11:21](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#11:21
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark"), and by [Mark
14:45](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Mark#14:45
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Mark") by
[Nathanael](/wiki/Bartholomew#Nathanael "Bartholomew") in [John
1:49](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#1:49
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"), where he is also called the
[Son of God](/wiki/Son_of_God "Son of God") in the same sentence.[119] On
several occasions, the disciples also refer to Jesus as Rabbi in the [Gospel
of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John"), e.g.
[4:31](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#4:31
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"),
[6:25](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#6:25
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"),
[9:2](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#9:2
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") and
[11:8](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#11:8
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John").[119][121]

Intimating that the title Rabbi was used by status seeking
[Pharisees](/wiki/Pharisees "Pharisees") (who "sit on the seat of Moses") and
use the title as sign of authority, in [Matthew
23:1-8](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Matthew#23:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Matthew") Jesus rejected the title of
Rabbi for his disciples, saying: "But be not ye called Rabbi: for one is your
teacher, and all ye are brethren".[119][121][122]

### Other names and
titles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Names_and_titles_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Other names and titles")]

The [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") uses several titles
to refer to Jesus. However, some terms that are commonly used in the Christian
tradition rarely appear in the New Testament, e.g. the exact term "Savior"
appears only once, and is uttered by the Samaritans in [John
4:42](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#4:42
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John").[123] The title
"[Nazarene](/wiki/Nazarene_\(title\) "Nazarene \(title\)")" applied to Jesus
has been also used to designate Christians in Syriac and Arabic
traditions.[124]

The title "Chosen one" or "Elect one" is used twice in Luke's gospel:
_eklektos_ is used in 23:35 when the rulers [mock
Jesus](/wiki/Mocking_of_Jesus "Mocking of Jesus"), while _eklelegmenos_ is
used in 9:35 when [Jesus is baptized](/wiki/Baptism_of_Jesus "Baptism of
Jesus"). [James R. Edwards](/wiki/James_R._Edwards "James R. Edwards") notes
that the phrase is used repeatedly in [1 Enoch](/wiki/1_Enoch "1 Enoch"), but
was associated in Jewish thinking with triumph and glory, rather than with
suffering.[125]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Minuscule_2444_%28GA%29_234_%28233%29.jpg/180px-
Minuscule_2444_%28GA%29_234_%28233%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minuscule_2444_\(GA\)_234_\(233\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Minuscule_2444_\(GA\)_234_\(233\).jpg "Enlarge")

A 13th century [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John"), the
only Gospel in which _[Bread of Life](/wiki/Bread_of_Life "Bread of Life")_
appears as one of the seven "[I am](/wiki/I_am_\(biblical_term\) "I am
\(biblical term\)")" assertions.[126][127]

Christian theologians such as [Thomas Aquinas](/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas "Thomas
Aquinas") have produced significant arguments analyzing various names and
titles for Jesus.[128] In [John
8:58](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#8:58
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") Jesus says: "Before Abraham was
born, I am." The phrase "[I am](/wiki/I_am_\(biblical_term\) "I am \(biblical
term\)")" (εγω ειμι in Greek) was considered a name for Jesus by Aquinas who
considered it the most proper of all divine names, for Aquinas believed it to
refer to the "being of all things".[129]

One of the titles preceded by an "[I am](/wiki/I_am_\(biblical_term\) "I am
\(biblical term\)")" assertion of Jesus is the "Bread of Life" title in [John
6:35](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#6:35
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John"): "I am the bread of life: he
who comes to me shall not hunger."[126] The [Bread of Life
Discourse](/wiki/Bread_of_Life_Discourse "Bread of Life Discourse") takes
place in the [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John") shortly
after Jesus feeds the crowds with five loaves of bread and two fish.[130]

In the [Epistle to the Hebrews](/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Hebrews "Epistle to the
Hebrews"), Jesus is called an "Apostle" and a "High Priest" in
[3:1](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Hebrews#3:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Hebrews"), the preparation for the two
titles being the preceding text of [Hebrews
2:5-18](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Hebrews#2:5
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Hebrews") which present the two
functions of Jesus: as an Apostle he represents God to humanity and as a High
Priest he represents humanity to God.[131]

While John's Gospel emphasizes Jesus as the [Son of God](/wiki/Son_of_God "Son
of God"), the [Gospel of Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke "Gospel of Luke") depicts
him as a [prophet](/wiki/Prophet "Prophet") above all else, attributing that
title to Jesus more often than even Mark.[132] A prophet is not someone who
merely preaches, but claims divine revelation through God.[133] In [Luke
4:24](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Luke#4:24
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Luke") following his [hometown
rejection](/wiki/Rejection_of_Jesus "Rejection of Jesus") episode, Jesus
remarks that as a prophet he is not welcome in his own hometown. Elsewhere, in
[Luke
7:39](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Luke#7:39
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Luke") the Jews again doubt that Jesus
is a prophet.[132] The view of Jesus as a prophet is used in the concept of
[threefold office](/wiki/Threefold_office "Threefold office") which sees his 3
roles as "Prophet, Priest and King".[134] While during [early
Christianity](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early Christianity") there were people
claiming to be prophets, there are no records of anyone else claiming to be a
prophet during the life of Jesus.[133]

In [John
14:16](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/John#14:16
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/John") Jesus said he will ask the
Father to send "another" [paraclete](/wiki/Paraclete "Paraclete"), i.e.
comforter.[135] The term paraclete only appears in [Johannine
literature](/wiki/Johannine_literature "Johannine literature") and apart from
the four uses in the [Gospel of John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John")
it appears only in [1 John
2:1](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_John#2:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 John").[135] Given that [1 John
2:1](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/1_John#2:1
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/1 John") views Jesus as a paraclete,
the reference in John 14:16 states that Jesus sends a second paraclete to
continue the life of the Church after his departure.[135] The statement
regarding the paraclete is made within the "farewell discourse" during the
[Last Supper](/wiki/Last_Supper "Last Supper") of Jesus and the Apostles.[136]
The paraclete is thus a link between the [ministry of
Jesus](/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus "Ministry of Jesus") and the future life of the
Church.[136]

Some titles of Jesus are unique to the [Book of
Revelation](/wiki/Book_of_Revelation "Book of Revelation"); he is referred to
as Faithful and True in [Revelation
19:11](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#19:11
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation"), the [Alpha and
Omega](/wiki/Alpha_and_Omega "Alpha and Omega") in [Revelation
22:13](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#22:13
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation") and elsewhere and the
Morning Star in [Revelation
22:16](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(American_Standard\)/Revelation#22:16
"wikisource:Bible \(American Standard\)/Revelation").
